column1: # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE MANUALLY. IT WAS GENERATED BY ETL step 'climate/latest/climate_change#climate-change'.

column2: Explore the impacts of global climate change.

column5: Global warming: heat content in the top 2,000 meters of the world's oceans
column6: Ocean heat content is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference. It is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, 10²² joules are equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.
column12: Heat content is shown for four sources: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP); National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and Meteorological Research Institute (MRI).
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column6: Mean seawater pH is shown based on in-situ measurements of pH from the Aloha station in Hawaii.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column6: Global mean sea level rise is measured relative to the 1993 - 2008 average sea level. This is shown as three series: the widely-cited Church & White dataset; the University of Hawaii Sea Level Center (UHLSC); and the average of the two.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column5: Climate change: Arctic sea ice extent
column6: The minimum and maximum sea ice extent typically occur in February and September each year.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column5: Climate change: Antarctic sea ice extent
column6: The minimum and maximum sea ice extent typically occur in February and September each year.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column5: Climate change: change in mass of ice sheets
column6: Cumulative change in mass of ice sheets, measured relative to a base year of 2002. For reference, 1,000 billion metric tons is equal to about 260 cubic miles of ice—enough to raise sea level by about 3 millimeters.
column12: Combined measurements are based on more than 20 different studies that have been combined for each region.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column5: Climate change: change of mass of US glaciers
column6: Cumulative mass balance of U.S. reference glaciers, relative to the base year 1965. This is given in meters of water equivalent, which represent changes in the average thickness of a glacier.
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column6: This metric measures the area covered by snow, based on an analysis of weekly maps. These data cover all of North America (including Greenland).
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column6: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm).
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column6: Atmospheric methane (CH₄) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
column14: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?
